January 19, 2021

I’ve finished reading the book “Who Was Michael Jackson?” by Megan Stine, and I can say with certainty that it disappointed me deeply.

The author shows cleverness at describing the early stages of Michael’s life, but when it comes to the late ‘80s till his passing, she was being too abbreviated and even took some of the rumors for granted.

We all know that Michael Jackson didn’t request to be called The King of Pop, it was Elizabeth Taylor who first had called him by this nickname in MTV music awards 1988, Michael talked about that in Winfrey’s interview with him in 1993, but in the book the author said that Michael Jackson told everyone to call him on the awards’ ceremony by this nickname, the book also admitted that Michael had so many plastic surgeries, which in the very same interview Michael declares that he only had two plastic surgeries on his nose, also, the author of the book claimed that Michael was the one who was messing with the press to get bad publicity by taking a picture of himself in an oxygen chamber, telling the world that he is buying the Elephant Man bones (Joseph Merrick), and having the chimpanzee bubbles as a pet, again, Michael had told Oprah that he was not sleeping in an oxygen chamber nor buying any bones at all, and clearly Michael had so many other animals too.

So, what I conclude is that there are two possibilities:

1. The author didn’t know about what Michael said on the ‘93 interview, thus she spoke of what she knew.

2. The author assumed that Michael was lying and she didn’t believe what he said.

And in both cases, one should say that this book was supposed to hold facts and the writer of a book should have all the proper information about the matter that they’re writing about.

The book mentioned the Child Accusations against Michael only in one page, the author mentioned the 1993 case settlement, the 2005 court vindication and Michael insisting on his innocence, all written in abstract in only one page, and that is fair to me because she didn’t say anything but informing the reader about what had happened without going into much unnecessary details, she was objective.

But that doesn’t mean that the book was bad at all, there were times when the author seemed to be in Michael’s side being amazed by his work as an entertainer and his message about healing the world and his humanitarian work, she also spoke about Michael’s activism against racism.

In conclusion, the book is great in terms of showing Michael’s early life and splendor talent, but it didn’t do good on the personal level.

And, I sincerely believe that we should separate the art from the artist, loving the work of an artist doesn’t mean that one shall know every personal detail available about them, the artist is a person who is sharing his capacities and talent with others, of course we must value them and for that reason we must understand that we have to be reasonable.

It hurts me a lot when I learn about Michael’s suffering because of people invading his personal space and privacy, I think it shall be a lesson for everyone to stop.

I recommend reading the book but with caution and checking every piece of information.

Have you read it already? Let me know your thoughts.

October 5, 2017

Michael Jackson is such a huge name, but my guess is many people don't know anything about his life. I certainly didn't. I had to hurry and read this book so I could help one of my students with their Wax Museum report.

Michael Jackson's life was all about becoming a star.

When he was just a young child, his dad pushed his kids to become the famous "Jackson 5." He worked them and worked them. Luckily, they did have a lot of natural talent. MJ had perfect pitch. His dad was abusive, though, and would often hit the children if they weren't doing what they were supposed to.

They first sang for Motown, but MJ broke away so he could have more control. He wanted to write his own songs and even star in movies. He starred in a movie called The Wiz with Diana Ross.

After the movie, MJ fired his dad as his manager and started working with Paul Quincy more on his own. It was at this time that he performed Thriller and the other songs he's famous for. He one the R&B Grammy award, but it made him mad because he thought of it as the "black" award and he felt he deserved the pop award. He started working harder.

He told MTV that he would only appear on their award shows if they called him "the king of pop." They did and it stuck.

He donated a lot of his money to charities, like a burn unit and helping kids with cancer.

He really loved his children and lived all over the world with them. He overspent and wasn't making any new songs so he got into serious debt. It was when he was trying to make a comeback that he died of an accidental drug overdose.

He also bought the rights to the Beatles songs and was kind of a dick to Paul McCartney and refused to give them more of the profits. Not cool.

It was interesting learning a little about this American legend.

January 28, 2023

was surprised to find this book had good info on michael jackson considering how false many of his unauthorized biographies are, but was once again disappointed that it focused on the unimportant things. while the book does mention that michael gave to charities and assisted many children, it seemed to emphasize his plastic surgery and painkiller reliance more.

“but he had tried to get attention in the wrong way” suggests that michael deserved the inhumane treatment by the media, and the malicious press attacks were of his own doing—no one wants that for themselves and michael never provoked any of it.

i did appreciate the fun quotes like “quincy jones’s recording engineer said michael jackson was one of the few people whose singing never had to be fixed in the studio. it was always perfect, just the way he sang it,” which underscore his insane talent.

the book doesn���t seem to take a stance on michael jackson’s innocence, which is weird because it should be crystal clear after performing enough research to write a book on him. i only wished the author made it more clear that he was a legendary humanitarian. after looking at the bibliography, which is only a mere 4 sources, i realized why this book was still lacking. to delve into one of the most misunderstood yet iconic figures in history but only rely on 4 sources is wild. especially when only 1 of them are from michael jackson himself and the rest are extremely biased and unreliable pieces—no one should read “michael jackson: the magic, the madness, the whole story.”

this was a quick and easy read but not fully accurate. still better than most books i’ve read on MJ

January 30, 2020

This book really told me the Michael Jackson had a really great but awful life at the same time. His life starts as a little kid in Indiana with 8 other siblings and a mom and dad to live with. And their house was really small. His career started when his brother Tito got caught playing his father's guitar. But instead of getting beat since his father was really strict, his father figured out that his father had talent. So he formed all the brothers into a band all the “Jackson 5”. Which later broke after the father's mental and physical abuse. Turns out, Michael had a great voice by himself. So he became a solo artist and had made lots of money and popularity with his songs Thriller, Billie Jean, Man in the Mirror, and etc. He later started getting a lot of plastic surgery on his nose after his dad made fun of his “Big Fat Nose” all the time. He also said he had a skin disease that turned him white after time. But people think that he bleached his skin all the time. He also later got accused of rape accusations to little kids. To which he ended up winning all the cases. In 2009, he announced his final worldwide tour of all his hit songs fans loved. But the day after practice performing, He was sent to the hospital after having a cardiac arrest. He died when he got to the hospital. One of his assistants was accused of killing him by giving him too many sleeping pills. After reading this, I now know that Michael was one of the most iconic artists in the music industry. I would recommend this to Michael Jackson lovers even though I don't really listen to his music.
